text.p: A joint Sino-Pakistan mountaineering expedition on Sunday conquered the 8,125-metre (26,660-foot) high Nanga Parbat peak in the north of Pakistan-controlled Kashmir, the official APP news agency said.

Six Tibetan Chinese and two Pakistani members of the expedition reached the summit of the Karakoram range peak, known as "killer mountain" for the many deaths of climbers on its slopes, at 11.15 a.m. (0615 gmt), it said.

The expeditions was jointly organised by China Tibet Mountaineering Association and Alpine Club of Pakistan to commemorate the golden jubilee celebrations of Pakistan's independence and consisted of 11 Chinese and six Pakistanis.

Bad weather last week forced another Pakistani-Chinese expedition, organised to mark the same occasion, to give up its attempt to scale the 8,847-metre (29,028-foot) high Mount Everest, the world's highest peak.
